column1: allthecanadianpolitics 160507322244 "2017-05-10 06:54:08 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/160507322244/tonight-i-volunteered-as-a-scrutineer-for-katrina "Tonight I volunteered as a scrutineer for Katrina Chen‚Äôs campaign; I met some wonderful candidate reps for the Darling (L) and Keithley (G) campaigns
column2: too. It was really great to engage in some earnest discussion while we watched the vote unfold. I noticed was we had a few ballots that were rejected or spoiled from the voter either being ignorant or trying to make some kind of point: checking off more than one candidate
column3: ranking candidates
column4: hand-rendered emojis and other doodles‚Ä¶ Please know your vote truly was truly wasted
column5: especially in such a close election. ¬†No one in this setting
column6: looking at your purposefully spoiled ballot
column7: is thinking anything other than ‚Äúthis is a spoiled ballot‚Äù. ¬†It get sealed in an envelope and sent away
column8: not to be reviewed meaningfully ever again by anyone who would see your ‚Äústatement‚Äù. If you want to make a point
column9: write your MLA. Make phone calls
column12: run a blog‚Ä¶spoiling your ballot purposefully wastes your time more than anyone else‚Äôs and fails that point-making exercise. It is no different than abstaining or apathy.‚ÄìSubmitted by¬†asbestoshazard." True text

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161065602934 "2017-05-25 18:56:54 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161065602934/brad-wall-says-sask-party-knew-budget-decisions "cosmicdwarf: allthecanadianpolitics:   Premier Brad Wall says the Saskatchewan Party knew provincial budget decisions meant the party would ‚Äúlikely see a decline in popularity with Saskatchewan voters‚Äù after a new poll suggests the NDP has taken a nine-point lead over the governing party.  The Mainstreet/Postmedia poll released Thursday suggests decided and leaning support for the NDP is at 49 per cent ‚Äî an increase of seven points ‚Äî compared to the Saskatchewan Party‚Äôs 40 per cent
column2: a drop of seven points. [‚Ä¶] The poll released Thursday suggests support for the NDP was most pronounced in Regina
column3: with 58 per cent of decided and leaning voters choosing the NDP under interim leader Trent Wotherspoon
column4: versus 29 per cent choosing the Saskatchewan Party led by Brad Wall. It suggests Saskatoon was slightly in favour of the NDP
column5: at 46 per cent
column6: with 42 per cent supporting the Saskatchewan Party. In the rest of the province
column7: support for the two parties was tied at 46 per cent.  Continue Reading.  Of course.¬† That is why they didn‚Äôt release a budget before their election. " False link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161065132164 "2017-05-25 18:40:10 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161065132164/reach-a-deal-by-monday-or-well-force-you-back-to "The Quebec government won‚Äôt let the province-wide construction workers‚Äô strike drag on ‚Äî Premier Philippe Couillard will table back-to-work legislation Monday if the two sides don‚Äôt come to an agreement before then.About 175
column2: 000 workers are off the job after talks between employers and unions sides broke down late Tuesday night
column3: bringing work on ongoing projects across the province to a halt.Couillard issued the ultimatum from Israel
column4: where he is in the midst of a trade mission.Michel Tr√©panier
column5: spokesperson for the alliance of unions
column6: said that parties would return to the negotiating table later today.‚ÄúI can tell you that all sectors will return to the negotiating table in the next hours
column7: ‚Äù he told Radio-Canada.Labour Minister Dominique Vien has made it clear she would prefer a signed agreement
column8: but would resort to a special law if need be.The government estimates the strike could mean losses of $45 million a day for the Quebec economy.Workers in the industrial sector are asking for more stable work schedules
column9: while salaries are believed to be the main sticking point in the residential sector.The workers have been without a collective agreement since April 30. Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161064562649 "2017-05-25 18:19:28 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161064562649/manitoba-makes-oct-4-official-day-to-honour-mmiwg "Manitoba politicians have voted: Oct. 4 will now be recognized in the province as the official day to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.Manitoba moves toward designating Oct. 4 to honour MMIWG‚ÄúI say meegwetch to all members of the assembly who supported Bill 221 to honour Manitoba‚Äôs missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and their families
column2: ‚Äù NDP MLA Nahanni Fontaine said in a release.‚ÄúThe families have long fought to draw attention to the crisis of violence against Indigenous women and girls.‚ÄùFontaine introduced the bill
column3: dubbed the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Honouring and Awareness Day Act. It received unanimous support Thursday during a vote at the Manitoba Legislature.Fontaine said the bill will bring more recognition to the plight of Indigenous women and girls in Canada. RCMP estimate more than 1
column4: 200 Indigenous women and girls have disappeared or been killed over the passed four decades.Vigils for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls have been held on Oct. 4 across Canada in recent years." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161064055242 "2017-05-25 18:00:49 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161064055242/montreal-police-officer-to-be-charged-with "More than a year after a man died after being shot by police with a rubber bullet in Montreal North
column2: a Montreal police officer is being charged with manslaughter. Bony Jean-Pierre
column3: a 46-year-old black man
column4: was shot during a drug raid gone wrong at an apartment complex on March 31
column5: 2016. He died a few days later from his injuries.After reviewing the evidence
column6: Quebec‚Äôs Crown prosecutor‚Äôs office (DPCP) announced Wednesday it has decided to charge Montreal police officer Christian Gilbert with manslaughter. Gilbert will appear in court on July 6.The DPCP said it would not be commenting on its decision
column7: as did the Montreal police department. Sentences for manslaughter in which a firearm is used range from a minimum of four years in prison to a life sentence.Jean-Pierre‚Äôs death led to unrest in the borough ‚Äî including a violent night of protest during which the local police station was vandalized ‚Äî and renewed calls for improved race relations in Montreal North.The protest had coincided with a vigil to commemorate the life of Fredy Villanueva
column8: an 18-year-old who was shot and killed by police in the borough in 2008. No criminal charges were ever filed against the officers involved.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161063934214 "2017-05-25 17:56:26 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161063934214/nigel-wright-broke-ethics-rules-during-mike-duffy "Former prime minister Stephen Harper‚Äôs one-time chief of staff was never prosecuted for his role in Mike Duffy‚Äôs Senate expenses fiasco but now Nigel Wright is getting a belated slap on the wrist from the federal ethics watchdog.In a long-awaited report released Thursday
column2: ethics commissioner Mary Dawson says Wright broke both the Parliament of Canada Act and the Conflict of Interest Act when he personally gave Duffy $90
column3: 000 to repay the Senate for questionable living expense claims.By giving Duffy the money as part of an agreement in which the senator was to reimburse the Senate and acknowledge the error of his ways
column4: Dawson says
column5: ‚ÄúMr. Wright was improperly furthering Sen. Duffy‚Äôs private interests
column6: ‚Äù sparing him the need to use his own funds. That‚Äôs a violation of conflict of interest rules.Moreover
column7: she says Wright broke another section of the act when he used his position as Harper‚Äôs right-hand man to try to influence Conservative bagman Sen. Irving Gerstein and the Conservative Fund Canada to dip into party coffers to reimburse Duffy‚Äôs expenses.Wright never faced any criminal charges for his role in the affair
column8: although Duffy was charged with 31 counts of fraud
column9: breach of trust and bribery. Wright was a prosecution witness during the subsequent trial
column10: which ended last spring with Duffy being found not guilty of all charges.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161063329216 "2017-05-25 17:33:55 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161063329216/she-should-have-been-safe-family-searching-for "Delilah Blair‚Äôs grieving mother is struggling to understand how her daughter could die in jail ‚Äì the one place she thought she would always be safe.‚ÄúWhen she was incarcerated I could sleep because I knew she wasn‚Äôt on the streets
column2: ‚Äù said Selina McIntyre. ‚ÄúShe should have been safe. They should have known her history. She wasn‚Äôt coming in there as a surprise.‚ÄùFemale inmate at South West Detention Centre dies after being found unresponsive in cellBlair‚Äôs family has identified her as the female inmate who died Sunday at the South West Detention Centre in Windsor
column3: Ont. McIntyre said the family was told by a coroner that her daughter hanged herself in her cell using bed sheets.The mother of four is the first inmate to die at the state-of-the-art facility since it opened in 2014. She was found unresponsive in her cell around 9 p.m. Corrections staff performed first aid and she was transported by ambulance to a Windsor hospital where she was declared dead. She was 30.The Office of the Chief Coroner
column4: the Ministry of Community Safety and Correctional Services and Windsor police are continuing to investigate.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161062609436 "2017-05-25 17:07:02 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161062609436/iveson-confirms-hell-seek-mayors-chair-again "Mayor Don Iveson used his annual ‚Äústate of the city‚Äù address on Wednesday to announce he will seek re-election in the Oct. 16 municipal election.Referring to himself as ‚Äúcollaborator-in-chief
column2: ‚Äù Iveson told an Edmonton Chamber of Commerce audience the city has made ‚Äúhuge progress‚Äù regionalizing its approach to economic development

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161062195599 "2017-05-25 16:52:04 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161062195599/gender-neutral-birth-certificates-could-be-issued "ayellowbirds:  deeyvthai:  allthecanadianpolitics:   Gender-neutral birth certificates could be issued in Ontario as early as next year
column2: provided the province can work out bureaucratic hurdles involving other governments. Ontario‚Äôs minister of government and consumer services said Thursday consultations will be held on the matter this summer and the province is working to ensure a gender-neutral birth certificate would be legally recognized in other jurisdictions. Tracy MacCharles said she‚Äôs hopeful Ontario can issue gender-neutral birth certificates by 2018.  Continue Reading.  Aren‚Äôt you just deciding the child‚Äôs gender before they can even speak anyway?How is this different from choosing boy or girl
column3: they didn‚Äôt get to choose it unlessyou‚Äôre referring to altering an existing document
column4: which you‚Äôre not

column6: not newborn children. " False link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161061881754 "2017-05-25 16:40:25 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161061881754/are-conservatives-trying-to-start-another "Remember the Harper government‚Äôs attack on progressive charities? Well
column2: it looks like Canadian conservatives are gearing up for Round 2.Last week
column3: Former Finance Minister Joe Oliver used his column in the Financial Post to complain about donations by American organizations to Canadian non-profits. This week
column4: a complaint filed with Elections Canada by a group called Canada Decides is alleging ‚Äúforeign influence‚Äù in the 2015 federal election
column5: even claiming that progressive organization Leadnow was ‚Äúspawned‚Äù by foreign money.The group
column6: fronted by former Conservative MP Joan Crockatt
column7: also includes two other directors: Brent Chapman the husband of former CPC MP Kerry-Lynne Findlay and Chad Hallman
column8: a conservative campus activist and U of T undergraduate. Chapman‚Äôs Facebook page appears to regularly promote right wing conspiracy theories about open borders and the funding of third party groups in Canada. Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161061769324 "2017-05-25 16:36:10 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161061769324/final-stretch-conservatives-to-gather-saturday " Conservative leadership candidates are working on getting out any remaining votes ahead of Saturday‚Äôs final event in Toronto
column2: at which the party will announce the successor to Stephen Harper.Officials estimate they‚Äôve already received 125
column3: 000 ballots from the party‚Äôs 259
column4: 010 members
column5: or nearly 50 per cent turnout. That sets a Canadian record for votes cast in a leadership race
column6: besting the Canadian Alliance‚Äôs 120
column7: 000 votes in 2000 and the more than 104
column8: 000 votes cast in the 2013 Liberal leadership that elected Justin Trudeau. The last Conservative Party race in 2004 saw about 97
column9: 000 ballots cast. Voter turnout for the 2013 Liberal leadership race was more than 80 per cent.That number of votes ‚Äúmakes this the largest leadership race in Canadian history
column10: ‚Äù said Conservative Party spokesman Cory Hann.Another 2
column11: 000 members have registered to be there in person to see the party announce its next leader.It‚Äôs the last week for voting in the contest
column12: which officially started last March. The party‚Äôs auditors
column14: must receive the votes by Friday at 5 p.m. unless members vote in person at one of the few local polling stations or at the main event in Toronto. For much of Canada
column15: that means ballots must have been cast before this week.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161061173283 "2017-05-25 16:13:56 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161061173283/federal-government-will-fund-new-water-project-for "Residents of the Enoch Cree Nation are one step closer to getting fresh water.The federal government on Wednesday announced a $12.5-million project to connect the reserve to the city of Edmonton‚Äôs water system.The project will build a new water supply line
column2: water reservoir and pump tank to provide drinking water for more than 2
column3: 000 community members.The reserve is currently under a boil water advisory due to high arsenic levels found in the community‚Äôs well water.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161060448167 "2017-05-25 15:47:03 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161060448167/political-neophyte-takes-aim-at-ndp-leadership "The lineup of higher profile candidates isn‚Äôt stopping Ibrahim Bruno El-Khoury from taking a shot at the federal NDP leadership.A management consultant who immigrated from Lebanon and became a Canadian citizen in 1996
column2: El-Khoury aims to make up ground against his already well-known opponents based on his professional experience and social justice ideals.He hasn‚Äôt yet raised the $30
column3: 000 entry fee or collected the signatures required to become an official candidate
column4: but El-Khoury‚Äôs bid has been approved by the party and he plans to become better known and promote his ideas out to the party members.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161059759494 "2017-05-25 15:20:28 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161059759494/conservatives-may-come-to-regret-ignoring-michael "When Michael Chong appeared on a stage in Edmonton months back with all of the current candidates running to lead the Conservative Party of Canada (Kevin O‚ÄôLeary was a no-show)
column2: he pitched his plan for a carbon tax ‚Äî and was booed
column3: loudly and long
column4: by the audience.He took the trouble to explain his plan in some detail ‚Äî how income taxes would be reduced proportionate to the impact of the tax on carbon emissions
column5: how it‚Äôs the socially and morally responsible thing to do. Didn‚Äôt matter. The scorn heaped upon him by party members was mirrored on stage
column6: as the remaining candidates lined up to resoundingly reject the notion of using a market-based tool to fight climate change.He tried gamely to convince the unfriendly audience that they should choose him as their next leader because he ‚Äî as the son of immigrants and a representative of the electorally critical ‚Äò905‚Äô area code ‚Äî had the best chance of the bunch of beating Justin Trudeau in 2019.Given how unpredictable the leadership contest was at the time ‚Äî and how unpredictable the next election remains ‚Äî his bold pitch was as valid as any other. In February
column7: the populist and ultra-nationalist campaign of Kellie Leitch had not yet burned itself out. It was still conceivable that a deeply polarizing candidate might emerge as the winner
column8: only to be soundly rejected by the broader electorate.But Michael Chong?Chong has both political and academic smarts. He understands that elections are won and lost in the suburbs of Canada‚Äôs major metropolitan centers. He understands that new Canadians form a large share of those demographics. He knows that some of the policies of intolerance the Conservatives bizarrely pushed in 2015 (banning the niqab at citizenship ceremonies
column9: a ‚Äòbarbaric practices‚Äô snitch line) were unforced errors that did the party irreparable harm in the suburbs.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161059075258 "2017-05-25 14:54:02 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161059075258/canada-150-douglas-jung-fought-for-canada-before "To mark Canada‚Äôs 150th birthday
column2: we are counting down to Canada Day with profiles of 150 noteworthy British Columbians.In February
column4: war veteran Douglas Jung returned home to Vancouver from Australia. Reporters wanted to ask him about his military activities during the Second World War
column5: but Jung couldn‚Äôt say a word about serving in a secret guerrilla unit.When Japan entered the war
column6: the British recognized the potential of using Chinese-Canadians as spies in Japanese-held territories. Jung was one of about 600 Chinese-Canadians who volunteered to fight ‚Äî even though they still weren‚Äôt recognized as full Canadian citizens.‚ÄúWe were people who
column7: even denied the most fundamental rights of citizenship
column8: acted as honourable citizens to serve our country in its hour of need
column9: ‚Äù he said at a military reunion of veterans in 1987. ‚ÄúAnd no one can take that honour away from us.‚ÄùIt wasn‚Äôt until 1947 that Chinese-Canadians were given the right to vote.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161058405747 "2017-05-25 14:27:06 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161058405747/indigenous-maternal-health-program-aims-to-address "Researchers in Toronto have received a $2.6 million grant to bolster Indigenous maternal and child health programs in an effort to close the gaps in health care that exist between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal families.The project
column2: which officially launches Thursday
column3: is called ‚ÄúKind Faces Sharing Places: An Action Research Project for Indigenous Families During and After Pregnancy and Birth.‚Äù It aims to bring better health care to First Nations populations
column4: some of which have infant mortality rates up to four times the national average.Racism against aboriginal people in health-care system ‚Äòpervasive‚Äô: studyPartnership aims to honour Indigenous cultural traditions at Windsor hospitals‚ÄúWe must break the unacceptable cycle of Indigenous family disruption using Indigenous values and practice to deliver family and community-centred
column5: culturally-appropriate care
column6: ‚Äù said Dr. Janet Smylie
column7: one of the program‚Äôs partners.Smylie is the director of the Well Living House at St. Michael‚Äôs Hospital
column8: a research centre for Indigenous infants
column9: children and families. It‚Äôs one of several partners working together on the program
column10: which is being funded through Merck Canada‚Äôs Merck for Mothers program.‚ÄúWe believe [the partners] have designed a really unique project
column12: executive director of the Merck for Mothers program
column14: it has community and women‚Äôs voices at the heart of it
column16: multi-sectoral approach to deal with all the upstream drivers that eventually lead to poor maternal and infant health outcomes.‚ÄùContinue Reading." True link

column2: 000 residential school survivors may finally be decided on May 25 when the question goes before the Supreme Court. The courts have consistently ruled it is up to the survivors to decide what happens to their own accounts of their experiences
column3: stories that led to Ottawa paying out more than $5 billion in compensation
column4: and that it is the survivors‚Äô wishes that must be upheld and respected. The courts say the 38
column5: 000 survivors have 15 years to decide individually if their stories should be preserved in an archive at the National Centre for Truth and Reconciliation (NCTR) at the University of Manitoba or be destroyed. But a coalition representing the children and grandchildren of residential school survivors was recently granted intervention status at the hearing. They want to save the 38
column6: 000 stories
column7: which they say are the largest firsthand accounts of the residential school system. ‚ÄúWhen I ask people if they want their story deleted
column8: I ask them to think about it in the intergenerational perspective
column10: founder of the Coalition to Preserve Truth and the artist behind the Witness Blanket
column12: art installation ‚Äî made up of leftover pieces of residential school items
column13: churches and government buildings. The blanket is currently touring the country. Newman is of British
column14: Kwagiulth and Salish descent.  Continue Reading.  I hope they do
column15: The last residential school closed in 1996
column16: And there already have individuals like   Lynn Beyak¬†attempting to alter and downplay the atrocities that were committed. " False link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161047518214 "2017-05-25 05:09:53 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161047518214/27-homeless-deaths-in-toronto-in-just-three-months "Homeless people in Toronto are dying at a rate of more than two per week on average
column2: according to disturbing new data collected by the city.From January to the end of March 2017
column3: a total of 27 homeless deaths were tracked in an expanded research initiative led by Toronto Public Health and supported by about 200 health and social services agencies. The median age of the deceased is 51.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a sign that our city is failing
column4: ‚Äù said City Councillor Joe Cressy (Trinity-Spadina). ‚ÄúIt seems to me that in a city as wealthy as ours that to have dozens of people dying on the streets is wrong
column5: it‚Äôs disturbing and it‚Äôs a failure on all of us. While we might not be able to prevent the loss of every life
column6: we certainly can prevent many of these if we do more.‚ÄùAdvocates for the homeless have long maintained that efforts thus far to accurately count the dead have under-reported the true scope of the tragedy.Previously
column7: the city has recorded deaths only in city-administered shelters; that number for all of 2016 was 33.The death rate for 2017
column8: if it continues at two per week through December
column9: would top 100 ‚Äî the most ever recorded in Toronto.Continue Reading." True link

column1: allthecanadianpolitics 161046648124 "2017-05-25 04:38:49 GMT" http://allthecanadianpolitics.tumblr.com/post/161046648124/university-of-saskatchewan-says-provincial-cut "The University of Saskatchewan says it has to close a research centre because funding was cut in the provincial budget.The Saskatoon-based school says the International Centre for Northern Governance and Development will close on June 15.The centre‚Äôs research has focused on concerns in areas such as northern governance
column2: First Nations and resource development
column3: northern innovation and climate and socio-economics.It also provided graduate-level degree programs.University president Peter Stoicheff says the university is ‚Äúdeeply disheartened‚Äù by the loss of provincial government funding for the centre.On Tuesday
column4: the University of Regina said eight staff will be laid off and 11 vacant positions will remain unfilled because of the Saskatchewan government‚Äôs funding cuts in its March budget." True link
